marketNews.title: Other Hot Topics You Need to Know
marketNews.content:
1. CNN reported that Thailand and Cambodia were engaged in a firefight along their shared border for the second consecutive day on Friday (25 July), with more than a dozen people reported dead and over 100,000 civilians evacuated. Tensions between the two countries have escalated over the past several months, driven by a territorial dispute along the land border.
2. Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs Airlangga Hartarto said on Thursday (24 July) that the exemption from TKDN requirements in the trade framework agreement with the United States does not apply to all U.S. products. He explained that the TKDN exemption applies only to information and communication technology (ICT) products, data centers, and medical device components. He added that these products must still comply with import regulations set by the technical ministries and be certified by the relevant authorities, such as the Food and Drug Authority.
3. Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs Airlangga Hartarto also stated on Thursday (24 July) that there is no removal of the ban on the export of Indonesia's critical minerals in the detailed framework of the trade agreement with the United States. He noted that the export of Indonesian minerals must continue to follow existing regulations, i.e., they must be processed domestically. His comment came after the White House announced that Indonesia agreed to lift restrictions on the export of industrial commodities, including critical minerals, under the trade framework.
4. The Indonesian Palm Oil Association (Gapki) estimates that Indonesia's palm oil exports will decline by about 5.1 percent year-on-year in 2025 to 28 million tons, due to higher domestic consumption driven by increased biodiesel blending, according to a Bloomberg report. Gapki's chairman, Eddy Martono, said that domestic palm oil production is expected to grow by 3.7 percent year-on-year in 2025 to 50 million tons. Gapki also projects that Indonesia's palm oil exports to the United States could rise from 2.2 million tons in 2024 to between 2.3 and 2.4 million tons in 2025 if tariffs on the commodity are reduced from the current 19 percent.
5. Subsidiary Sumber Global Energy (SGER) and Bintang Mitra Semestaraya (BSMR) signed an amendment to their syndicated loan agreement, increasing the facility from 160 billion rupiah to 350 billion rupiah, with an option to raise it to 600 billion rupiah. The loan is intended for the construction of Indonesia's second-largest hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) plant, with an annual production capacity of 20,000 metric tons.
6. Chief Commissioner of Nusa Raya Cipta (NRCA), Johannes Suriadjaja, sold approximately 1.8 million NRCA shares at an average price of 1,015 rupiah per share on 21 July 2025, totaling about 1.8 billion rupiah. After this transaction, his ownership in NRCA fell from 0.15 percent to 0.08 percent. On the same day, PT Persada Capital Investama purchased 4 million NRCA shares at an average price of 815 rupiah per share, totaling about 3.3 billion rupiah, raising its ownership from zero to 0.16 percent.

tickerNews.title: BBNI 1H25: Net Profit Down 6% YoY, Below Expectations
tickerNews.content: Bank Negara Indonesia (BBNI) reported a net profit of 4.7 trillion rupiah for the second quarter of 2025, a decrease of 12 percent year-on-year and 12 percent quarter-on-quarter. This result makes the net profit for the first half of 2025 total 10.1 trillion rupiah, down 6 percent year-on-year, below expectations as it represents only 46 percent of the 2025 consensus estimate (versus an average of 50 percent annual realization over the past two years). Net profit was pressured by weak Pre-Provision Operating Profit (PPOP) and higher provisions. PPOP fell 5 percent year-on-year in Q2 and 2 percent year-on-year in the first half, as Non-Interest Income declined 2 percent year-on-year in Q2 and 3 percent year-on-year in the first half, while operating expenses rose 5 percent year-on-year in Q2 and 3 percent year-on-year in the first half. Net Interest Income was relatively stable, increasing 0 percent year-on-year in Q2 and 2 percent year-on-year in the first half, but far below credit growth of 7 percent year-on-year as of June 2025, highlighting margin pressure. Net Interest Margin (NIM) fell to 3.7 percent in Q2 2025 (versus 4.0 percent in Q2 2024 and 3.9 percent in Q1 2025) due to high cost of funds, leaving the first-half NIM at 3.8 percent (versus 4.0 percent in the first half of 2024). Provision expenses rose to 2 trillion rupiah in Q2 2025, up 15 percent year-on-year and 15 percent quarter-on-quarter, resulting in total provisions of 3.8 trillion rupiah for the first half, up 8 percent year-on-year. The Non-Performing Loan (NPL) ratio stood at 1.9 percent in Q2 2025 (versus 2.0 percent in Q2 2024 and 2.0 percent in Q1 2025). The consumer segment saw NPL increase to 2.1 percent (versus 1.6 percent in Q2 2024 and 2.0 percent in Q1 2025), mainly driven by mortgage and auto financing, which management attributes to weakened purchasing power. Management did not provide a full explanation of the involvement in the Merah Putih Village Cooperative, but said discussions with the government consider all stakeholders. In credit granting, the bank will conduct borrower assessments and expects the credit allocation to remain manageable. Key takeaway: the weakness in Q2 aligns with earlier notes. After releasing the first-half results, BBNI lowered its 2025 NIM guidance from a range of 4.0-4.2 percent to a minimum of 3.8 percent, despite expecting banking liquidity to improve in the second half of 2025 due to lower yields and SRBI holdings, a reduction in the BI rate, and accelerated government spending. The credit growth guidance of 8-10 percent year-on-year and Cost of Credit around 1 percent remain unchanged.

tickerNews.title: PANI Clarifies Rumor of Rights Issue
tickerNews.content: Pantai Indah Kapuk Dua (PANI) issued a clarification to the Indonesia Stock Exchange on Thursday (24 July) stating that the company never gave any official statement to the media regarding a rumor of a rights issue at the end of this year. PANI also affirmed that as of the date of the clarification, the company had not announced any plan to conduct a rights issue. The statement followed a Bloomberg Technoz report on Wednesday (23 July) that PANI would launch a rights issue with an execution price of 20,000 rupiah per share in December 2025, and that the company would announce it soon. PANI explained in its clarification that it remains open to all possibilities and alternatives related to corporate actions—including rights issues—to support its expansion plans and business continuity.

tickerNews.title: UNTR Reports Heavy Equipment Sales and Coal Production
tickerNews.content: United Tractors (UNTR) reported sales of 379 units of Komatsu heavy equipment in June 2025, a decline of 18.1 percent month-on-month and 2.8 percent year-on-year. Cumulatively for the first half of 2025, Komatsu sales reached 2,728 units, up 27.1 percent year-on-year, representing 59 percent of the 2025 target of 4,600 units, with market share stable at 26 percent (versus 26 percent in the first half of 2025 and 28 percent in the first half of 2024). In the mining contractor segment, UNTR recorded coal production volume of 68.4 million tons, down 1.6 percent year-on-year during the first half of 2025, with overburden removal of 532.8 million cubic meters, down 9.4 percent year-on-year.

tickerNews.title: BTPS Posts Highest Quarterly Net Profit Since 2Q23
tickerNews.content: Bank BTPN Syariah (BTPS) reported a net profit of 333 billion rupiah in the second quarter of 2025, up 16 percent year-on-year and 7.2 percent quarter-on-quarter, marking the highest quarterly profit since 2Q23. This result brings the net profit for the first half of 2025 to 644 billion rupiah, a 17 percent year-on-year increase, in line with expectations (51 percent of the 2025 consensus estimate, versus 52 percent annual realization in the first half of 2024). The profit increase was driven by a 41 percent year-on-year reduction in provision expenses in Q2 and a 42 percent year-on-year reduction over the first half, with Cost of Credit falling to 7.8 percent in Q2 2025 (versus 12.7 percent in Q2 2024 and 8.5 percent in Q1 2025) and 8.2 percent for the first half (versus 13.3 percent in the first half of 2024). The gross NPF fell to 3.1 percent from the end-of-year level, still higher than the same period last year (versus 3.7 percent in 4Q24 and 3.0 percent in 2Q24). PPOP continued to decline, down 13 percent year-on-year over the first half, while Net Margin Income weakened by 4.9 percent year-on-year.

tickerNews.title: DMAS Reports Decline in Marketing Sales
tickerNews.content: Puradelta Lestari (DMAS) reported marketing sales of 114 billion rupiah in the second quarter of 2025, down 79 percent year-on-year and 76 percent quarter-on-quarter. This results in marketing sales of 580 billion rupiah for the first half of 2025, a decline of 47 percent year-on-year, representing approximately 32 percent of the 2025 target of 1.81 trillion rupiah. The company's Director and Corporate Secretary, Tondy Suwanto, stated that industrial land sales amounted to 18 hectares in the first half of 2025 (versus 34 hectares in the first half of 2024 and 14.2 hectares in Q1 2025). He noted that the data-center sector was the main driver of first-half marketing sales, contributing 69 percent. He also disclosed that there remains demand for about 75 hectares of industrial land, dominated by the data-center sector, which accounts for more than 50 percent of the demand.

tickerNews.title: IPCC Achieves Strong Net Profit Growth
tickerNews.content: Indonesia Kendaraan Terminal (IPCC) reported a net profit of 63 billion rupiah in the second quarter of 2025, up 48 percent year-on-year and 22 percent quarter-on-quarter, resulting in a first-half net profit of 114 billion rupiah, a 41 percent year-on-year increase. Revenue in Q2 2025 grew to 212 billion rupiah, up 15 percent year-on-year and 4 percent quarter-on-quarter, leading to first-half revenue growth of 15 percent year-on-year to 416 billion rupiah. In addition to revenue growth, the solid net profit increase in Q2 was mainly driven by an expansion of gross profit margin to 43.2 percent (versus 35.4 percent in Q2 2024 and 38.2 percent in Q1 2025), resulting in gross profit growth of 40 percent year-on-year and 18 percent quarter-on-quarter.
